sections: We‚Äôre sending you a second email today so you can read the biggest story I‚Äôve written in ages, one I spent all week reporting from the heart of the region that handed Donald Trump the presidency. Running for governor of Pennsylvania, Democrat Josh Shapiro is all that‚Äôs standing in the way of all-out fascism ‚Äî and he happens to be my old high school buddy. It‚Äôs why I traveled to my home state to spend some behind-the-scenes time with Shapiro on the final leg of his statewide campaign. I asked some tough questions, got some interesting responses ‚Äî and found a bit of hope for what lies ahead, but not in the way I expected. Find out what I discovered
below ‚Äî and read to the very end, if you can. There are some important lessons.

On a foggy autumn morning in the heart of the region that handed Donald Trump the presidency, Josh Shapiro is quoting Hebrew scripture to a boisterous throng fearing the worst in the upcoming election.

‚ÄúI do what I do because of my faith,‚Äù the Democratic gubernatorial nominee tells the rapt crowd at the Cro Club, a Croatian bar and bowling alley that‚Äôs smelled of beer and cigarettes since before Western Pennsylvania‚Äôs steel mills closed a half century ago. ‚ÄúMy scripture says no one is required to complete the task, but neither are we free to refrain from it, meaning each of us has a responsibility to get off the sidelines, get in the game, and do our part.‚Äù

The rhetoric is half rabbi and half motivational speaker, and the white hairs and union guys here in Donora cheer it on like screaming fans at a rock concert, which is funny because Shapiro doesn‚Äôt look the part of a rustbelt folk hero.

This short, clean-shaven, bespectacled Jewish pol from a leafy suburb on the other side of the state should be a fish out of water in this West Virginia-ish part of Pennsylvania long written off by the national Democratic Party. But instead of emanating an outsider‚Äôs off-putting, John-Kerry-asking-for-Swiss-on-a-cheesesteak

, Shapiro somehow fits in. He exudes a mix of Huey Long populism and Ted Lasso can-do-ness, rousing the crowd with jeremiads against ‚Äústudent loan companies that rip off our students‚Äù and ‚Äúthe greed of pharmaceutical company board rooms‚Äù that sowed the opioid epidemic in Appalachia.

as a future Democratic presidential contender, Shapiro, 49, is campaigning in Republican territory in the final days of the gubernatorial race for his so-called ‚ÄúBig Fights Bus Tour‚Äù ‚Äî and the battles he has waged as Pennsylvania‚Äôs attorney general are top of mind among the cheering crowd.
One old timer tells me Shapiro‚Äôs barrage of lawsuits against health care and fracking companies shows ‚Äúhe‚Äôs the only one who seems like he‚Äôs doing anything in Harrisburg.‚Äù

Giving me a tour of the building‚Äôs ancient duckpin bowling lanes, Cro Club owner Jim Brandemarte confides that he‚Äôs a practicing Catholic but likes that Shapiro ‚Äúhad the guts to go after the priests‚Äù ‚Äî a reference to the
Shapiro ever brought as the state‚Äôs top law enforcement official.

Watching the scene, I can‚Äôt help but think Shapiro ‚Äî my old Junior Jewish Basketball League buddy from the Philly suburbs ‚Äî may have found the recipe I‚Äôve spent a quarter century hunting for: the one that channels working-class rage away from culture wars and into populist economics, rather than insisting the rage is

I first caught a glimpse of that recipe back in the late 1990s when I was Bernie Sanders‚Äô press secretary, watching the self-described socialist bash billionaire greed and rack up votes in Vermont‚Äôs conservative Northeast Kingdom. I saw the recipe again in the mid 2000s when Canadian health care
his way into becoming the wildly popular Democratic governor of deep red Montana. I even published an
likening the quest for the elusive recipe to a hunt for the Da Vinci Code.

But that political formula ‚Äî people-versus-powerful populism that names the corporate villains ‚Äî has all but disappeared from a Democratic Party whose politicians, pundits, and affluent NPR-soothed voters seem to pine instead for a return to a pre-Trump epoch of
etiquette and Barack Obama bromides about bipartisanship.
Though he hails from the comfortable Philadelphia suburbs, Shapiro has eschewed the stereotype of an effete complacent liberal dripping with

condescension toward small-town Pennsylvania. From his clashes with Wall Street money managers, fossil fuel companies, predatory lenders, and other bad guys, he‚Äôs built a reputation as a competent crusader trying to stop the boot endlessly kicking the face of the little guy.
He‚Äôs evaded some necessary battles over
and clashed with some in his party over
issues, but his recipe of carefully selected ‚Äúbig fights‚Äù with powerful institutions helped make him his state‚Äôs
and deterred a contentious gubernatorial primary two years later.

Now with this year‚Äôs general election the stakes are even higher ‚Äî which is why I traveled halfway across the country back to hang with him in the state where I grew up. At a time when so many Democrats seem unserious about stopping right-wing authoritarianism, I wanted to see if my childhood friend could be the exception in his race against the most conservative gubernatorial candidate in the country.

So far, things look good: Shapiro has been defying the national trends and leading in the polls. Then again, survey data has been increasingly unreliable. Last year, the Democratic governor of neighboring New Jersey ‚Äî a much bluer state than Pennsylvania ‚Äî was
by a virtual unknown. Shapiro‚Äôs current polling
is only a bit larger than Hillary Clinton‚Äôs
over Trump in Pennsylvania in the fall of 2016 ‚Äî and we all know how that turned out.

If things break bad this week and Shapiro doesn‚Äôt overperform in the so-called Pennsylvania T ‚Äî the vast red ocean we‚Äôre traveling through between Pittsburgh and Philadelphia and along the northern tier of the state ‚Äî his 20-year electoral winning streak could come to an end.
‚ÄúI Could Decertify Every Machine In The State‚Äù

You wouldn‚Äôt know there‚Äôs so much at stake in this gubernatorial race by Shapiro‚Äôs demeanor this chilly overcast morning in a parking lot behind a motel near McKeesport. He is standing in front of a camera waiting for a CNN interview, passing the time by cracking self-effacing jokes.

‚ÄúThis woman came up to me and said I‚Äôm usually so boring on TV, she says she couldn‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm an okay public speaker,‚Äù he recounts to his staff, then, with a healthy dose of dad energy gleaned from being the father of four, tests out understated campaign mottos. ‚ÄúShapiro for governor: Eh, he‚Äôs OK‚Ä¶ Shapiro For Governor: Have you seen the other guy?‚Äù
When the interview kicks off, he‚Äôs repeatedly pushed to weigh in on national issues, but he deflects with a practiced aw-shucks routine about being just a local guy focused on local stuff.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not paying a whole lot of attention to what the president‚Äôs plan is or what people in Washington, D.C., are paying attention to or talking about, I‚Äôm focused on what Washington County, Pennsylvania, needs,‚Äù he says in a typical rejoinder.

The segment ends with anchor Don Lemon complimenting Shapiro‚Äôs black jacket, and Shapiro replying: ‚ÄúWell, Don Lemon knows how to dress, so if you like the Ted Lasso puffy coat, that‚Äôs a good deal here, Don.‚Äù
It‚Äôs a light moment in an otherwise dark political war that has an
intensity to it. Shapiro presents as the cheery mensch your Jewish grandmother really wanted you to be. He is up against Republican state senator and January 6
Doug Mastriano, the kind of martial supervillain that your Jewish grandfather insisted was coming to kill you in the night.

If that seems overstated, consider that a few years after a gunman massacred worshipers at Pittsburgh‚Äôs Tree of Life synagogue, Mastriano ‚Äî a former Army colonel and Christian nationalist ‚Äî had his campaign
thousands of dollars to court support from users of a far-right social media website that‚Äôs been a haven for white supremacists, including
Shapiro‚Äôs childhood schooling at a Jewish day school to depict him as an elitist. He also
dressed up as a Confederate soldier
to overturn Pennsylvania‚Äôs 2020 presidential election ‚Äî an effort
Now Mastriano is campaigning for governor on a promise to work with Pennsylvania‚Äôs Republican legislature to
and to crush unions with so-called
. He‚Äôs also threatening to use gubernatorial power to overturn presidential election results he doesn‚Äôt like.
‚Äú[As governor] I get to appoint the Secretary of State, who‚Äôs delegated from me the power to make the corrections to elections, the voting logs, and everything,‚Äù Mastriano
on a local right-wing radio station. ‚ÄúI could decertify every machine in the state with a stroke of a pen.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve had a lot of tough elections,‚Äù Shapiro tells me on his campaign bus as we drive past the faded brick facades and hollowed-out main streets of the mill towns in the Mon Valley, named after the Monongahela River. ‚ÄúBut never one against an opponent this dangerous, never one where I‚Äôm scared about what the opponent would do to our institutions if he wins.‚Äù
against Shapiro himself, after his campaign
ads that seemed to boost Mastriano ‚Äî the most extreme GOP candidate ‚Äî in the final days of the Republican primary. Critics

the Democrat‚Äôs desire for a general election contrast prompted him to play with fire and help the most dangerous potential candidate secure the nomination and get one step closer to winning the governorship.

So far, though, the gambit seems to have worked ‚Äî Shapiro has relentlessly spotlighted Mastriano‚Äôs most incendiary statements and behavior in ad after ad, so successfully portraying him as a dangerous extremist that a mere eight years after Pennsylvania had a GOP governor, the national Republican Governors Association has declined to spend money on the race.
full of union money, Shapiro has outspent Mastriano on TV ads by a count of $26 million to about $2 million, according to data from AdImpact ‚Äî and the polls reflect that advantage.

‚ÄúJosh is a good candidate and very skilled,‚Äù says U.S. Rep. Brendan Boyle (D-Pa.), who served in the state legislature with Shapiro. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs also the case that when Mastriano won the primary, we were all like, ‚ÄòWow, this is great, the Republicans just ceded it to us.‚Äô We definitely got lucky in this environment.‚Äù

If Boyle‚Äôs analysis holds on election day, it will be another victory in a streak of Shapiro decisions that have ‚Äî so far ‚Äî successfully navigated a state with some of America‚Äôs most fractured racial, reproductive, gun, environmental, and economic politics.
Pennsylvania has large and vibrant Black communities, while ranking
the list of states with hate groups. It is the home of pro-choice suburbs, but also of Catholic communities who in the 1980s helped elect history‚Äôs most famous anti-choice Democrat,
. It is a state whose old-money neighborhoods in Philadelphia and Pittsburgh abut crushing poverty.

show Pennsylvania‚Äôs electorate generally wants limits on fossil fuel development and gun control, but its most politically pivotal swing counties remain deeply tied to coal and natural gas, and the state also has had among the
highest gun ownership rates in America

These contradictions produce their own oxymorons in politics: a congressional delegation split between the parties, and a Democratic governor facing a Republican legislature. Such complex terrain tends to reward shrewd politicos like Shapiro, whose commitment to retail politics and to methodically ascending the political ladder seems downright quaint in the modern age of self-funded first-timers, celebrities, and carnival barkers running shoot-the-moon candidacies for high office.
Shapiro‚Äôs political journey began with one of the few discernible stumbles in his life.
He grew up in Philadelphia‚Äôs northern suburbs, now infamous for being the fake home of New Jersey TV doctor-turned-Senate candidate Mehmet Oz, and the

of private equity billionaire Steve Schwarzman, one of the Republican Party‚Äôs largest donors. After graduating from a local Jewish high school, he tried to follow in his pediatrician father‚Äôs footsteps, but flunked out of pre-med at the University of Rochester. Soon after, he just missed making the school‚Äôs Division III basketball team. That‚Äôs when a friend of his told him to run for student government.
‚ÄúI asked him why should I do that?‚Äù he reminisces with a smile. ‚ÄúAnd he says, ‚ÄòWell, what else do you have to do now?‚Äô‚Äù

The rest of the story writes itself: Shapiro out-hustled his older opponents to become the first freshman elected student body president. Upon graduation, he worked for two Democratic senators, and then, after marrying his 9th-grade sweetheart, Lori, he became chief of staff for his new hometown Democratic Congressman Joe Hoeffel, only the second Democrat elected to the suburban congressional seat in the previous three decades. Three years later, with a Georgetown law degree in hand, Shapiro headed from D.C. back to Montgomery County and began winning elections in years that were otherwise tough for his party.

First up, 2004: While George Bush was getting reelected in the middle of the Iraq War, Shapiro was bootstrapping a successful campaign to unseat the local Republican icon, state Rep. John Fox ‚Äî an affable moderate known mainly for constituent service and for showing up to anything and everything in town.

‚ÄúHe had 99 percent name ID and was super popular,‚Äù Shapiro recounts. ‚ÄúEvery organization was run by Republicans, so they wouldn‚Äôt even let me speak. I remember coming home all pissed off, and then like she‚Äôs done to me throughout my life about this stuff, Lori yelled at me and told me, ‚ÄòYou better figure out some other way to talk to people.‚Äô‚Äù

‚ÄúThe next day I put on a comfortable pair of shoes, and I started knocking doors,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI knocked on 18,000 doors myself. On Labor Day, we did a poll and we were losing by literally 40 points. But I ended up winning.‚Äù
Once in office, Shapiro refused to internalize Harrisburg‚Äôs go-along-to-get-along culture, instead helping engineer the overthrow of the existing Republican House Speaker (who was soon after
to open up the secretive legislature to more transparency, and Shapiro getting himself
deputy speaker of the lower chamber.
Next up, in 2011, as Democrats were being tossed out of state and local offices all over the country, Shapiro led Democrats‚Äô takeover of the Montgomery County commission for the
. He pulled it off with a campaign for commissioner that
more budget discipline and no new taxes ‚Äî a record he
in his gubernatorial race, though he later
to add back funding to the county‚Äôs community colleges. Shapiro also made
firing the financial firms that had been charging county workers‚Äô pension fund high fees for weak returns.
Then came the attorney general race in 2016 ‚Äî another terrible year for Democrats. With the support of
, Shapiro defeated a Pittsburgh-area district attorney and his powerful machine in a hard-fought statewide primary, and then became Pennsylvania‚Äôs
in the same general election that Trump won the state and the presidency.

Now atop his party‚Äôs 2022 ticket, Shapiro still defies simple labels. Interviews with Democratic politicos yielded descriptions of him as progressive, centrist, right-of-center, and center-left ‚Äî the latter of which came from one of his former colleagues in the legislature.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs very organized, he works incredibly hard, but I think it‚Äôs fair to say he‚Äôs maintained a center-left profile the whole time, and I think that‚Äôs critical to winning statewide in Pennsylvania,‚Äù says former state auditor Eugene DePasquale, who served with Shapiro in the state Assembly. ‚ÄúBut when you see Josh, you don‚Äôt think ‚ÄòWhoa, he‚Äôs out there way on the left,‚Äô because stylistically, he doesn‚Äôt present like that. And I think that‚Äôs more what people want as a governor.‚Äù

DePasquale tells me this while cheering Shapiro on at a nighttime campaign rally in the parking lot of the Pittsburgh Steelers stadium. At the same rally, one of the state‚Äôs best-known progressives suggests to me that Shapiro‚Äôs label-defying profile reflects a skill of particular value this election cycle.

‚ÄúJosh has been doing a great job of unifying a party in a state where things really, really go badly and things with another candidate could have been completely different,‚Äù says Democratic state Rep. Summer Lee, the progressive who won tough primaries for legislature and Congress. ‚ÄúBut from the primary to now, Josh has navigated it masterfully. There‚Äôs so many other races for governor [where] we‚Äôre seeing a Republican surge, but to see Josh being able to avoid that speaks to his skill.‚Äù

In that style and presentation, Shapiro is a throwback to an earlier age: a disciplined, non-celebrity, no-schtick, big-D Democrat ‚Äî without a conditional adjective anchoring him to one or another party faction. He has forged a brand that is ‚Äúambitious without being ruthless, principled without being rigid,‚Äù as

He‚Äôs also something of a unicorn in American politics: Though he ascended in the Clintonian era of political triangulation, he is a serious Democratic politician who doesn‚Äôt make a show of punching left, even when he disagrees with his party‚Äôs base. That tracks with his disdain for his national party‚Äôs reputation for condescension.

‚ÄúHave you ever noticed how Democrats talk about college and student debt?‚Äù he says to me on our way to a rally at Bloomsburg University. ‚ÄúThey say, ‚ÄòWell, maybe college just isn‚Äôt for everybody.‚Äô And it‚Äôs like they‚Äôre looking down at people.‚Äù
His approach seems to have trickled down to the voter level as an image of competence. At every event on this bus tour, attendees describe him first and foremost as down-to-earth and
and not a novice or a bomb thrower. A workhorse, not a show horse.

‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt deal in fearmongering,‚Äù a retired retail worker named Bernadette from Indiana, Pennsylvania, tells me. In the Mon valley, a retired welfare department worker named Rick Pankiewicz tells me Shapiro is ‚Äúa fair-minded politician who supports the law ‚Äî that‚Äôs the crux of what an attorney general should do.‚Äù

Western Pennsylvania state Rep. Pam Snyder (D) put it this way: ‚ÄúJosh has been a state representative. He was county commissioner of one of the largest counties. You know, if I go to the doctors today, and they tell me I need brain surgery. I don‚Äôt want the guy that‚Äôs gonna miss. I want the guy who knows what he‚Äôs doing and who understands people.‚Äù
A cynic might say there‚Äôs a

quality to Shapiro‚Äôs journey ‚Äî cold, calculating, cutthroat. He certainly remains just as hyper-competitive as I remember him from our Jewish basketball league days ‚Äî indeed, when I ask if he still plays, Lori says his problem is that whenever he and his four kids play, he always has to try to win.

Shapiro‚Äôs rise, though, has not been marked by thumb-in-the-wind equivocation. His record isn‚Äôt full of betrayals on matters like gun control, abortion, union rights, education funding, or protecting jobs. Those are Shapiro‚Äôs central issues, and always have been ‚Äî even when the political winds were shifting.

‚ÄúHe is focused, ambitious, and careful, there is no doubt about that,‚Äù said Jordan Marks, who served in former Democratic Gov. Ed Rendell‚Äôs administration and has known Shapiro since before he first ran for office. ‚ÄúHe also really has core values that have propelled him to where he is today.‚Äù

As attorney general, Shapiro had the opportunity to take an easier path that many Democrats favor. He could have merely fought Trump‚Äôs 2020 election lawsuits, basked in the cable TV glory of those victories, cast himself as a #Resistance Liberal, and avoided clashes with powerful opponents who often play hardball in elections.

Outside a carpenters‚Äô union training center in Republican-dominated Blair County, Shapiro is getting to what is clearly his favorite part of his stump speech. It comes after all his cheery Lasso-eque aphorisms imploring voters to ‚Äúget in the game.‚Äù You can tell he loves this other part, the chip-on-the-shoulder, tough-guy part. His pace picks up, and his voice rises to the edge of hoarseness.
‚ÄúWe need a governor who knows how to take on big fights,‚Äù he tells the union crowd. ‚ÄúI know something about big fights.‚Äù
Over the last few days, he‚Äôs filled this particular section of his rallyfesto with stories of his time in the attorney general‚Äôs office. Today, it‚Äôs the tale from one of his

open ‚Äúthe largest Davis Bacon wage theft case in the history of the United States‚Äù ‚Äî a case where he criminally charged a government construction contractor ‚Äúwho took advantage of Pennsylvania workers who were doing back-breaking work on Pennsylvania roadways and ripped them off to the tune of $21 million.‚Äù
Then he takes it a step further, pivoting to a tough-on-crime message that sounds like it‚Äôs about to echo Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúAmerican carnage‚Äù lingo.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve locked up 8,200 drug dealers, who brought poison into our communities ‚Äî you bring those poisons into our communities, especially when you sell to our kids, we will arrest you,‚Äù he says.

Then he adds a twist: ‚ÄúBut this opioid crisis we‚Äôre dealing with today wasn‚Äôt manufactured on our street corners here in Blair County. No, it was manufactured by the greed of pharmaceutical company executives in their boardrooms. So I took them to court and won and brought a billion dollars of their ill-gotten gains back to Pennsylvania.‚Äù

From the moment he was sworn in, Shapiro seemed to appreciate that the attorney general‚Äôs office comes with a political downside and an upside. You run the risk of being blamed for a rise in street crime that you might have little power to stop. However, in the era of rage at unaccountable elites, you can use the office to pursue the bad guys and brag about it.

The latter strategy is less frequently used by many politicians, because it can enrage business interests that bankroll super PACs and dark money groups. But from the get-go, Shapiro leaned into the enforcer role, forging the ‚Äúbig fights‚Äù reputation that has become one of his gubernatorial campaign themes and that distinguishes him from the typical consensus-venerating, norms-worshiping Democrat.
Out of the gate, he made international headlines
sexual abuse in the Catholic Church ‚Äî not necessarily a politically safe move from a Jewish elected official in one of America‚Äôs most Catholic states.
one of the state‚Äôs largest health care systems to force it to stop denying medical care to nearly 2 million people in Western Pennsylvania.
A little while later, he successfully sued a fracking company for polluting Washington County, in the process exposing what his office
a ‚Äúsystematic failure by government agencies‚Äù to regulate the industry.
to beat back Trump‚Äôs attempt to help corporations weaken wage protections for tipped workers.
Then came the case against student loan giant Navient. Despite the potential electoral risk of targeting such a huge company headquartered in his own state, Shapiro
accusing the company of misleading student borrowers away from a more affordable repayment program.
Finally, this summer, he won a
against a multi-state mortgage lender, and
one of the country‚Äôs largest pipeline companies on criminal charges related to water pollution.

and in Shapiro‚Äôs stump speeches, he and his campaign sound almost Republican, only because this is the thing Republicans have mastered and today‚Äôs Democrats almost never do: lean into conflict and name bad guys.

That strategy has extended to Shapiro‚Äôs campaign against Mastriano. In both his speeches and his $26-million ad campaign, he has cast his battle against the Republican as another ‚Äúbig fight‚Äù ‚Äî portraying the GOP state senator not merely as an extremist, but as a

At a time when so many Democrats wish their party would run the kind of ruthless campaigns against the GOP that Republicans always run against them, Shapiro has actually done that ‚Äî insinuating that Mastriano is essentially a criminal, but one Shapiro frames as just another perp on his fight card.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not done with the big fights because in six days we got another one when we all come together and defeat Doug Mastriano,‚Äù he tells the crowd. ‚ÄúThis guy must be defeated. He is uniquely dangerous. If you don‚Äôt think like Doug Mastriano, if you don‚Äôt look like Doug Mastriano, if you don‚Äôt vote like him, if you don‚Äôt worship like him, if you don‚Äôt marry like him, then you don‚Äôt count in his Pennsylvania.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat The Hell Are We Doing Here?‚Äù

As his red-white-and-blue bus rolls through the twisty back roads of coal country in the late afternoon, Shapiro looks like he‚Äôs about to puke. I tell him I‚Äôve finally discovered this perpetual election winner‚Äôs kryptonite: car sickness.
‚ÄúIs that going in your story?‚Äù he asks with a chuckle.

He agrees to take some meds from Lori, who is sitting one row ahead of him on the bus, as long as it‚Äôs non-drowsy ‚Äî understandable, since we‚Äôre headed to another nighttime rally, this one in downtown Harrisburg.

It‚Äôs the last leg of my three-day road trip with the campaign, and he thanks me for coming back east to hang with him. Throughout the journey he‚Äôs been texting me pictures he‚Äôs snapped of me talking to folks at rallies and meet-and-greets, reminding me that ‚Äúit‚Äôs good to be with real people and out of the bubble‚Äù and not focus so much on what he calls ‚Äúthe bullshit.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe get too caught up in the bullshit of what do people look like, what are they wearing, where do they come from, but I focus on showing up and making sure people know that I‚Äôve got their back,‚Äù he tells me. ‚ÄúWe get so caught up in things that don‚Äôt matter, but I always keep in mind that at the end of the day, what matters is: Do you have a record and do you have a plan to make things better for people?‚Äù
My jaded internal narrator might have eyerolled that ‚Äî but after a few days out here, I‚Äôm feeling a tad less cynical.
The truth is, after working on so many demoralizing campaigns and being let down by enough politicians, I was hesitant to take this trip because I felt
. I didn‚Äôt want to do the one thing Ted Lasso ‚Äî and Josh Shapiro ‚Äî really want you to do: believe.
But my swing through my old home state has made me believe, at least a little bit.
No, I don‚Äôt believe Shapiro is above criticism. For starters, while he‚Äôs led some major criminal justice reforms, he‚Äôs elicited the
of criminal justice reformers with his unwavering support for police ‚Äî something he‚Äôs plugged in a
. Prosecutors in the state‚Äôs two biggest cities also
him for an opioid settlement they said was too small.
Meanwhile, among his inflation relief plans, Shapiro is
a corporate tax cut that could
the state of some resources and help companies already reaping windfalls ‚Äî
perhaps, but not exactly working-class populist.
Then there‚Äôs this: While Shapiro tells me my climate-themed apocalypse
freaked him out, and he has rightly
his GOP opponent‚Äôs climate denialism, in fracking country I see Shapiro tout his support for an ‚Äúall of the above‚Äù energy policy, and it remains unclear what he would do about the
allies over climate policy in a state that is one of America‚Äôs largest fossil fuel producers.

‚ÄúThe stuff he talks about everyday ‚Äî workers rights, education funding, reproductive freedom, voting rights ‚Äî I know in my bones that he will always fight for those things,‚Äù says Marks, the Democratic operative. ‚ÄúBut there are other things that we don‚Äôt know how he‚Äôll govern on, and he tries to walk a very fine line on those things, whether it is energy or corporate tax subsidies. These are areas we don‚Äôt know exactly where he will be.‚Äù

State Sen. Katie Muth, a Democrat who represents part of Shapiro‚Äôs own Montgomery County and has pressed Shapiro to get tougher with the fossil fuel industry, echoes that sentiment. She tells me that while she credits Shapiro for his fighting spirit in the battle against polluters, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm concerned that some of the battles are performative and designed to get headlines with no real follow-up. He‚Äôs incredibly calculated and makes decisions in a very strategic way. But the governor‚Äôs office is about follow-up and details.‚Äù
So yeah, if Shapiro wins, big fights and unanswered questions remain.
And yet, here is what I came to believe as I traveled from Pittsburgh to Harrisburg: Shapiro is the
of politician a functioning democracy should probably reward.

If you‚Äôve read this far, this is likely the point where you expect me to tell you Shapiro is a messianic savior on his way to the White House. In our culture of followership and fandom, that would probably generate more clicks.
But as much as I like Josh and as well as I know him, the line from his own stump speech is correct: It‚Äôs really not about believing in
. It‚Äôs about believing in something bigger.
